content.description: In an experiment, a cylinder of height <math alttext="0.10 meter " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and cross-sectional area <math alttext="0.004 meters squared" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0.004</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> has a movable piston with negligible mass and contains an ideal gas. The gas is taken through cycle <math alttext="A B C A " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as its absolute pressure and volume are recorded. The graph shows the best-fit curves for the data.
content.question: When the gas reaches state <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the piston is momentarily held in place by an applied force. What is the magnitude of this applied force?

topic.text: 9.1: Kinetic Theory of Temperature and Pressure

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
